case_title: Dispute Between Home Buyer and Promoter for Project MY CITY - PHASE II - CLUSTER 4
case_description: A home buyer disputes the terms of the agreement for sale presented by the promoter, citing ambiguities and contradictions with the cost sheet provided at booking. The buyer seeks execution of an amended agreement and compensation for delays.

sections.section_title: Section 13 of the RERA Act, 2016: No Advance Without Agreement for Sale
sections.section_description: A promoter shall not accept more than 10% of the cost of the apartment, plot, or building as an advance or application fee without first entering into a written agreement for sale with the buyer. This agreement must specify development details, timelines, and the possession date.

sections.section_title: Section 11 of the RERA Act, 2016: Obligations of the Promoter
sections.section_description: Promoters must ensure transparency by disclosing all relevant project details, such as sanctioned plans, layout plans, cost estimates, and timelines. They must also ensure that advertisements and agreements align with the registered project details.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Right to Compensation for Delays
sections.section_description: If the promoter fails to deliver the project as per the terms of the agreement for sale, the buyer is entitled to withdraw from the project with a full refund and interest. Alternatively, the buyer may continue with the project and receive interest for the delay until possession is granted.

sections.section_title: Section 12 of the RERA Act, 2016: Compensation for False or Misleading Advertisements
sections.section_description: If a buyer suffers loss due to false or misleading information in the advertisement or prospectus, they are entitled to compensation. The promoter is liable to return the amount paid by the buyer along with interest.

strong_points: Complainant raised concerns about ambiguities in the draft agreement and discrepancies from the cost sheet.
Complainant’s willingness to pay the remaining amount and proceed with the project.
weak_points: Complainant has paid only 4% of the total consideration, falling short of the RERA requirement.
No signed agreement for sale exists to substantiate claims.

case_title: Complaint No. CC006000000480080 - Sachin Babu Gurav vs Damodar Suruchi Developers Pvt. Ltd.
case_description: Sachin Babu Gurav filed a complaint seeking directions from MahaRERA to hand over possession of flat no. 108 in Wing B of the project 'UK Iridium', along with interest and compensation for delayed possession. The matter was referred to MahaRERA Conciliation Forum, where both parties resolved the issue amicably. The complaint was subsequently withdrawn following the signed consent terms.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Compensation for Delays in Possession
sections.section_description: If a promoter fails to deliver possession of a property as per the terms of the agreement, the buyer is entitled to withdraw and claim a refund with interest. Alternatively, the buyer may choose to remain in the project and seek interest for the delay until possession is handed over.

sections.section_title: Section 32(g) of the RERA Act, 2016: Promoting Conciliation
sections.section_description: MahaRERA has the responsibility to facilitate amicable resolution of disputes between promoters and buyers through its Conciliation Forum, promoting a fair settlement process.

sections.section_title: Section 4(2)(l)(D) of the RERA Act, 2016: Adherence to Timelines
sections.section_description: The promoter must adhere to the timelines and specifications mentioned in the agreement for sale. In case of non-compliance, buyers have the right to seek remedies under RERA.

sections.section_title: Section 71 of the RERA Act, 2016: Authority’s Powers for Adjudication
sections.section_description: MahaRERA has the power to hear disputes and ensure compliance with the provisions of the Act. Conciliation and adjudication are part of this process, and parties may resolve issues amicably under the Authority's guidance.

strong_points: Both parties agreed to resolve the matter amicably through the MahaRERA Conciliation Forum.
Consent terms were signed and the matter was officially recorded as resolved.
weak_points: The complainant did not appear at the final hearing nor submitted any objections to the consent terms or withdrawal application.

case_title: Complaint No. CC005000000258951 - Shirish Govind Sukhatme vs Om Developer
case_description: Shirish Govind Sukhatme filed a complaint seeking directions from MahaRERA for the respondent to show 12 flats booked by him as sold inventory in the project 'Tropica Phase II'. The complaint was withdrawn after MahaRERA confirmed that the flats were reflected as sold on the website.

sections.section_title: Section 11 of the RERA Act, 2016: Obligations of the Promoter
sections.section_description: Promoters are required to provide accurate and transparent information regarding the status of inventory, including sold and available units, on the MahaRERA website.

sections.section_title: Section 34 of the RERA Act, 2016: Functions of the Authority
sections.section_description: The Authority is responsible for maintaining an updated database of registered projects, including details of sold and available inventory, to ensure transparency and protect buyers' interests.

sections.section_title: Section 31 of the RERA Act, 2016: Filing of Complaints
sections.section_description: Any aggrieved person can file a complaint with MahaRERA if they believe there is a contravention of the Act or Rules, such as incorrect or missing inventory details.

sections.section_title: Section 71 of the RERA Act, 2016: Authority’s Powers for Adjudication
sections.section_description: MahaRERA has the power to resolve disputes and verify complaints, including ensuring the accuracy of project details, such as inventory listings.

strong_points: The complainant verified that the flats were listed as sold inventory on the MahaRERA website after MahaRERA's review.
The complaint was resolved amicably without further legal action.
weak_points: The complainant initially believed the flats were not listed as sold inventory, leading to the complaint.

case_title: Complaint No. CC006000000055076 - Mr. Shekhar Bhargav Devlekar vs M/s. Nirmal Lifestyle (Kalyan) Pvt. Limited
case_description: Shekhar Bhargav Devlekar filed a complaint seeking compensation for delayed possession of a flat. The complaint was withdrawn after both parties signed consent terms, but a non-execution application was later filed due to non-compliance with the terms.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Compensation for Delays in Possession
sections.section_description: If a promoter fails to deliver possession of a property as per the terms of the agreement, the buyer is entitled to withdraw and claim a refund with interest. Alternatively, the buyer may continue with the project and seek interest for the delay until possession is handed over.

sections.section_title: Section 72 of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016: Claims Against Insolvent Entities
sections.section_description: If a respondent is undergoing insolvency proceedings, any claims for compensation or unpaid dues must be filed with the appointed Resolution Professional overseeing the insolvency process.

sections.section_title: Section 34 of the RERA Act, 2016: Functions of the Authority
sections.section_description: MahaRERA has the responsibility to ensure compliance with its orders and assist complainants in resolving disputes, including directing them to alternative legal remedies when necessary.

sections.section_title: Section 71 of the RERA Act, 2016: Authority’s Powers for Adjudication
sections.section_description: MahaRERA is empowered to hear complaints and applications, such as non-execution filings, but its jurisdiction is limited when insolvency proceedings are involved.

strong_points: The complaint was resolved through consent terms, and both parties agreed to settle amicably.
The complainant took proactive steps to address non-compliance.
weak_points: The respondent failed to comply with the consent terms, leading to the non-execution application.

case_title: Complaint No. CC006000000192449 - Mr. Hamendra Kasturlal Doshi vs M/s. Rite Developers Pvt. Ltd.
case_description: Mr. Hamendra Kasturlal Doshi filed a complaint seeking interest for delayed possession of flat no. 1504 in the project 'Rite Skyluxe,' as per the agreement for sale dated 29/06/2017. Although possession was delayed beyond the agreed date of 31/03/2018, the flat was eventually handed over on 07/01/2020. The complainant alleges contravention of the agreement and seeks compensation under Section 18 of RERA.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Compensation for Delays in Possession
sections.section_description: If the promoter fails to deliver possession by the agreed date, the allottee is entitled to withdraw from the project and claim a refund with interest or continue with the project and claim compensation for the delay.

sections.section_title: Section 71 of the RERA Act, 2016: Adjudication of Compensation Claims
sections.section_description: The Adjudicating Officer is empowered to decide on claims for compensation under Section 18, ensuring fair resolution of disputes.

sections.section_title: Section 11(4)(a) of the RERA Act, 2016: Promoter's Obligations for Timely Possession
sections.section_description: Promoters are obligated to adhere to the terms of the agreement for sale, including delivering possession within the stipulated timeline.

strong_points: The complainant paid the full consideration as per the agreement and sought interest for delay within legal provisions.
MahaRERA recognized the applicability of Section 18(3), which entitles the complainant to compensation for delayed possession.
weak_points: The respondent cited changes in government policy as a factor beyond their control, leading to delays.
The complainant signed the possession letter, which the respondent argues constitutes a waiver of claims.

case_title: Complaint No. CC006000000057281 - Mr. Anil Gulabdas Shah vs M/s. Solaris Developers Private Limited & Anr.
case_description: Mr. Anil Gulabdas Shah filed a complaint seeking a refund of the full amount paid for flat no. 1601 in the project 'Solaris Titanium Tower' under Section 18 of RERA, citing non-receipt of an occupancy certificate. Although the complainant had taken possession of the flat in 2013, the MahaRERA observed that the promoter failed to obtain the occupancy certificate and referred the case for compensation under Section 18(3) of RERA.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Compensation for Delays in Possession
sections.section_description: If the promoter fails to deliver possession by the agreed date, or fails to obtain the occupancy certificate, the allottee is entitled to withdraw and claim a refund with interest or continue with the project and seek compensation for delays or lapses.

sections.section_title: Section 71 of the RERA Act, 2016: Adjudication of Compensation Claims
sections.section_description: The Adjudicating Officer is empowered to decide the quantum of compensation payable to the complainant in cases involving violations under Section 18.

sections.section_title: Section 11(4)(a) of the RERA Act, 2016: Promoter’s Obligations
sections.section_description: The promoter is responsible for obtaining the occupancy certificate and adhering to the terms of the agreement for sale, ensuring the timely and lawful transfer of the property to the allottee.

sections.section_title: Section 19(10) of the RERA Act, 2016: Obligations of the Allottee
sections.section_description: An allottee is obligated to make payments and take possession of the property as agreed. However, they retain the right to seek compensation if the promoter fails to comply with statutory obligations, such as obtaining the occupancy certificate.

strong_points: The complainant emphasized the lack of an occupancy certificate for the flat, which is a significant lapse by the promoter.
MahaRERA acknowledged the applicability of Section 18(3) of RERA, entitling the complainant to seek compensation for the promoter’s failure.
weak_points: The complainant had already taken possession of the flat in 2013, which weakened his case for a full refund.
The respondent cited their application for an extension of the project validity period, suggesting ongoing compliance efforts.

case_title: Complaint No. CC006000000055459 - M/s. Nisar Properties Pvt. Ltd. vs Mr. Shaikh Haroon Rashid & Mr. Shaikh Abuzar Haroon Rashid
case_description: M/s. Nisar Properties Pvt. Ltd. filed a complaint seeking payment of outstanding dues along with interest under Section 19(6) of RERA for a flat in the project 'Rajal-Om Jaishriram CHS Ltd.' The complainant also sought compensation of Rs. 10,00,000/- for mental agony caused by the respondents' alleged violations of RERA. Although possession was handed over in January 2018, the complainant stated it was done without prejudice to their claims for dues and compensation.

sections.section_title: Section 19(6) of the RERA Act, 2016: Allottee's Obligation to Pay Dues
sections.section_description: An allottee must make all payments for the property as per the agreement for sale, including any installments. Failure to pay dues can result in legal claims from the promoter along with interest for the delay.

sections.section_title: Section 72 of the RERA Act, 2016: Factors for Determining Compensation
sections.section_description: The Adjudicating Officer must consider the nature of default, mental agony, and the extent of loss caused to the complainant when determining the quantum of compensation.

sections.section_title: Section 11(4)(a) of the RERA Act, 2016: Promoter's Obligations for Timely Recovery
sections.section_description: Promoters are required to ensure compliance with agreements, including the timely recovery of dues. They are entitled to seek legal remedies if allottee obligations are unmet.

sections.section_title: Section 3 of the MOFA Act, 1963: Disclosure Obligations
sections.section_description: Under the Maharashtra Ownership of Flats Act, promoters are required to disclose all details of agreements and financial obligations clearly. This reinforces transparency in payment disputes.

sections.section_title: Section 71 of the RERA Act, 2016: Adjudication of Compensation Claims
sections.section_description: The Adjudicating Officer is empowered to hear and decide compensation claims related to violations under RERA, including disputes about unpaid dues and related harassment claims.

strong_points: The complainant provided evidence of outstanding dues as per the agreement for sale.
MahaRERA acknowledged the applicability of Sections 71 and 72, empowering the Adjudicating Officer to decide on compensation.
weak_points: The respondents disputed the claims but did not provide a strong defense or written submissions to challenge the complainant’s allegations.
The complainant had already handed over possession of the flat, potentially weakening their position regarding claims of harassment.

case_title: Complaint No. CC006000000292629 - Pradip Shripat Patankar vs M/S. Sheltrex Karjat Pvt Ltd
case_description: Pradip Shripat Patankar filed a complaint seeking a refund of the full booking amount paid for flat no. 1603 in Building Y10 of the project 'Sheltrex Smart Phone City Project 1 - Phase II,' along with interest under the provisions of RERA. However, the respondent has been admitted into Corporate Insolvency Resolution Process (CIRP) as per the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) order, leading to a moratorium under Section 14 of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016. Consequently, MahaRERA has adjourned the complaint sine die.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Refund for Non-completion or Delays
sections.section_description: If the promoter fails to complete or deliver possession of a property as agreed, the allottee is entitled to a refund of the amount paid along with interest. Alternatively, the allottee can claim compensation for delays while continuing with the project.

sections.section_title: Section 14 of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016: Moratorium
sections.section_description: Once a company is admitted into Corporate Insolvency Resolution Process (CIRP), a moratorium is imposed prohibiting the initiation or continuation of legal proceedings against the debtor until the process is resolved.

sections.section_title: Section 19(6) of the RERA Act, 2016: Allottee’s Rights in Case of Non-compliance
sections.section_description: The allottee has the right to demand a refund or compensation for violations under the terms of the agreement, especially in cases of delays or failure to deliver the project.

sections.section_title: Section 71 of the RERA Act, 2016: Adjudication of Compensation Claims
sections.section_description: The Adjudicating Officer is empowered to decide on claims related to compensation under RERA. However, jurisdiction is subject to restrictions like the moratorium under IBC.

strong_points: The complainant has already taken proactive steps by filing a claim with the appointed IRP under the CIRP.
MahaRERA provided clarity on the legal constraints due to the moratorium under Section 14 of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code.
weak_points: The moratorium prevents MahaRERA from taking any immediate action or providing relief to the complainant.
The respondent’s insolvency proceedings could significantly delay the complainant’s ability to recover the booking amount or seek compensation.

case_title: Complaint No. CC005000000043784 - Mr. Umesh Sandipan Magar & Mts. Jyoti Umesh Magar vs M/s. Kul Developers Pvt Ltd. & M/s. Ashdan Developers Private Ltd.
case_description: The complainants filed a complaint seeking a refund of the amount paid for flat no. 1103 in the project 'VTP Beaumonde-Nation R2 Tower 5,' along with interest and compensation under Section 18 of the RERA. The respondents failed to hand over possession of the flat on the agreed date of possession as per the registered agreement for sale. The case was transferred to the Adjudicating Officer of MahaRERA for determination of the compensation and interest under Section 18 of the RERA.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Refund and Compensation for Delays
sections.section_description: If the promoter fails to hand over possession by the agreed date, the allottee is entitled to withdraw from the project and claim a refund along with interest and compensation. Alternatively, the allottee may continue and seek compensation for delays.

sections.section_title: Section 71 of the RERA Act, 2016: Adjudication of Compensation Claims
sections.section_description: The Adjudicating Officer is empowered to decide the quantum of compensation payable to the allottee in cases involving delays or breaches under Section 18.

sections.section_title: Section 11(4)(a) of the RERA Act, 2016: Promoter’s Obligations
sections.section_description: Promoters are obligated to adhere to the terms of the agreement for sale, including delivering possession within the stipulated timeline. Failure to comply constitutes a breach under RERA.

sections.section_title: Section 19(10) of the RERA Act, 2016: Allottee’s Rights in Case of Delay
sections.section_description: The allottee is entitled to seek remedies for delays or breaches by the promoter, including refunds, interest, and compensation as specified under RERA.

strong_points: The complainants provided a registered agreement for sale and demonstrated non-compliance by the respondent with the agreed possession date.
MahaRERA recognized the respondents' failure to explain the delay and their previous non-compliance with an order issued in 2018.
weak_points: The case was transferred to the Adjudicating Officer for determining the compensation, potentially delaying relief for the complainants.
The respondents have not clarified the revised completion timeline for the project, which could impact the complainants' claim.

case_title: Complaint No. CC006000000198586 - M/s Aditya C HS Ltd vs M/s Navkar Builders and Developers
case_description: The complainant filed a complaint seeking directions from MahaRERA for the respondent to fulfill statutory and contractual obligations, complete the project, and compensate the society of allottees for expenses. The complaint also addressed the delay in project completion and possession of flats, citing violations under Sections 11, 18, and 19(3) of the RERA.

sections.section_title: Section 11 of the RERA Act, 2016: Obligations of the Promoter
sections.section_description: Promoters must fulfill statutory obligations, provide accurate disclosures, and ensure the timely completion of the project as per the agreement for sale.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Refund and Compensation for Delays
sections.section_description: If the promoter fails to deliver possession by the agreed date, the allottee or society of allottees is entitled to a refund or compensation for the delay, along with interest.

sections.section_title: Section 19(3) of the RERA Act, 2016: Rights of the Allottee
sections.section_description: The allottee has the right to claim possession of the property as per the terms of the agreement for sale and the timelines specified therein.

sections.section_title: Section 14 of the RERA Act, 2016: Adherence to Sanctioned Plans
sections.section_description: Promoters must execute the project in accordance with the sanctioned plans and cannot make any alterations or delays without the consent of the allottees.

strong_points: The complainant presented a detailed account of delays and non-compliance by the respondent, including the failure to hand over possession and the absence of updates on the project’s progress.
MahaRERA acknowledged the statutory violations and the need for further hearings to resolve the issues.
weak_points: The respondent failed to provide a clear explanation for the delay in construction and possession, and their reply lacked specifics on some key issues raised during the hearings.
The case was adjourned for further proceedings, which may delay the final resolution of the complainant’s claims.

case_title: Complaint No. CC006000000171668 - Smitesh Shivaji Patil vs Hubtown Limited
case_description: The complainant has filed a complaint regarding the delay in possession of an apartment purchased from the respondent’s project, ‘Hubtown Greenwoods D Wing.’ The complainant seeks interest on the delay and possession of the apartment, citing failure to meet the stipulated possession date as per the agreement for sale.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Refund and Compensation for Delays
sections.section_description: If the promoter fails to deliver possession by the agreed date, the allottee is entitled to withdraw from the project and claim a refund with interest or continue and seek compensation for the delay.

sections.section_title: Section 19(3) of the RERA Act, 2016: Allottee’s Right to Possession
sections.section_description: The allottee has the right to claim possession of the property as per the terms of the agreement for sale and within the specified timeline.

sections.section_title: Section 14 of the RERA Act, 2016: Adherence to Sanctioned Plans
sections.section_description: Promoters must execute the project as per the sanctioned plans and agreements, without undue delay or deviations, except with the consent of the allottees.

sections.section_title: Section 4 of the MOFA Act, 1963: Promoter’s Obligations
sections.section_description: Promoters are obligated to complete the construction and provide possession as per the terms agreed upon in the agreement for sale.

strong_points: The complainant presented a clear case of non-compliance with the possession date, and MahaRERA acknowledged the delay.
MahaRERA has provided clear directions for the completion of the project and handling the delay once the occupancy certificate is obtained.
weak_points: The respondent failed to provide a specific timeline for the completion of the project or when possession could be handed over.
The case was deferred to a final order, which may delay the resolution for the complainant.

case_title: Complaint Nos. CC006000000078474, CC006000000078478, CC006000000078481, CC006000000079205, CC006000000089928 - Vinay Arvind Ranade & Others vs The Bombay Dyeing and Manufacturing Company Limited
case_description: The complainants filed complaints against The Bombay Dyeing and Manufacturing Company Limited, alleging failure to execute agreements for sale, and non-compliance with promised project timelines. The complainants seek a refund with interest and compensation, citing issues with the agreement for sale and non-completion of the project as promised. The dispute revolves around the delayed possession and non-execution of sale agreements despite the project nearing completion.

sections.section_title: Section 12 of the RERA Act, 2016: Refund for False or Misleading Representations
sections.section_description: If any promoter provides false or misleading information in advertisements or brochures, or fails to comply with commitments, the allottee is entitled to a refund of the amount paid along with interest and compensation.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Refund and Compensation for Delays
sections.section_description: If the promoter fails to complete or deliver possession as per the agreement, the allottee may withdraw from the project and claim a refund with interest or choose to continue and seek compensation for the delay.

sections.section_title: Section 13 of the RERA Act, 2016: Advance Payment and Agreement for Sale
sections.section_description: A promoter cannot accept more than 10% of the cost of the property as an advance or application fee without first executing a registered agreement for sale with the allottee.

sections.section_title: Section 4 of the MOFA Act, 1963: Promoter’s Obligations
sections.section_description: Promoters are obligated to execute agreements and provide possession of the property as per the terms agreed upon, ensuring transparency and adherence to timelines.

strong_points: MahaRERA acknowledged the complainants' entitlement to a refund under Section 12 of the Real Estate Act and transferred the complaints to the Adjudicating Officer for further adjudication.
The project was nearing completion, and the respondent had obtained the occupancy certificate, indicating progress on the project.
weak_points: The respondent's failure to execute the agreements for sale and provide timely possession led to the complaints.
The project nearing completion did not prevent the complainants' legitimate claims under the Real Estate Act, potentially delaying the final resolution.

case_title: Complaint No. CC005000000053927 - Mr. Swapnil Shahaji Patil vs M/s. Maple Buildcon
case_description: The complainant filed a complaint seeking a refund of the amount paid for a flat booked in the respondent's project, 'Aapla Ghar Ambegaon Annex-Phase 1', due to the failure to hand over possession of the flat as per the agreement. The complainant paid a substantial amount but no possession was given, and the project was reportedly at a standstill. The complainant seeks a refund under section 18 of the RERA Act.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Refund and Compensation for Delays
sections.section_description: If the promoter fails to complete or deliver possession by the agreed date, the allottee may withdraw from the project and claim a refund with interest. Alternatively, the allottee may continue and seek compensation for the delay.

sections.section_title: Section 13 of the RERA Act, 2016: Advance Payment and Agreement for Sale
sections.section_description: A promoter cannot accept more than 10% of the cost of the property as an advance or application fee without first executing a registered agreement for sale with the allottee.

sections.section_title: Section 11 of the RERA Act, 2016: Obligations of the Promoter
sections.section_description: Promoters are obligated to provide accurate disclosures and ensure adherence to statutory obligations, including timely completion of the project and possession as agreed.

sections.section_title: Section 4 of the MOFA Act, 1963: Promoter’s Obligations
sections.section_description: Promoters must fulfill their obligations under the agreement for sale, including the timely handover of possession as per the agreed terms.

strong_points: The complainant's claim for a refund is supported by the lapsed possession date in the agreement for sale.
The transfer of the case to the Adjudicating Officer ensures that the complaint will be adjudicated in accordance with RERA provisions.
weak_points: The respondent's claim that the complaint is premature, as the project completion is scheduled for 31-12-2022, was not sufficient to dismiss the complaint.

case_title: Complaint Nos. CC006000000078311 to CC006000000192983 - Various Complainants vs Ricardo Constructions Private Limited
case_description: Multiple complainants, including individuals and the US OPEN (ACES/MATCH POINT) AOA, filed complaints against Ricardo Constructions Pvt. Ltd. regarding delays in the project 'Ace and Matchpoint' at Mulund, Mumbai. The complainants seek refunds, possession of flats, or the execution of agreements for sale. The case involves the transfer of the project to a new promoter under the provisions of Section 15 of the RERA Act.

sections.section_title: Section 11 of the RERA Act, 2016: Obligations of the Promoter
sections.section_description: The promoter is required to adhere to approved project plans and specifications, ensure timely possession, and execute agreements for sale for buyers who have paid over 10% of the property price. The failure to complete the project in a timely manner makes the promoter liable for compensation or refunds with interest.

sections.section_title: Section 15 of the RERA Act, 2016: Transfer of Real Estate Project
sections.section_description: This section specifies that the promoter cannot transfer the majority rights and liabilities in a project without the prior written consent of at least two-thirds of the allottees and approval from MahaRERA. This is directly relevant to the transfer of the project to the new promoter.

sections.section_title: Section 19 of the RERA Act, 2016: Rights and Duties of Allottees
sections.section_description: Allottees have the right to receive timely possession of their apartments and demand refunds or compensation for delays. They also have the right to participate in the formation of an association or society to safeguard their interests.

sections.section_title: Section 13 of the RERA Act, 2016: No Deposit or Advance Without Agreement for Sale
sections.section_description: The promoter cannot accept more than 10% of the apartment cost as an advance without executing a registered agreement for sale. This is relevant for buyers seeking agreements from the promoter.

strong_points: MahaRERA's decision ensures that the allottees' interests are protected, with a transparent approach for monitoring project progress.
The decision includes specific timelines for actions, such as the execution of agreements for sale and initiation of society formation.
weak_points: The respondent may face challenges in meeting the strict timelines set by MahaRERA, especially considering the ongoing project delays.

case_title: Complaint No. CC006000000161244 - Avinash Dudumkar & Devyani Dudumkar vs Safal Realtors And Developers Pvt Ltd & Ors.
case_description: The complainants, Avinash Dudumkar and Devyani Dudumkar, filed a complaint against Safal Realtors And Developers Pvt. Ltd. for non-execution of a registered agreement for sale and failure to hand over possession of a flat (No. 1001) in the project '22 Dhuleva'. They seek a refund of the money paid, along with interest and compensation under Section 18 of the RERA.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Refund and Compensation for Delays
sections.section_description: If the promoter fails to complete the project or is unable to give possession of the property in accordance with the terms of the agreement, the allottee is entitled to a refund of the amount paid along with interest and compensation as determined by the Authority.

sections.section_title: Section 13 of the RERA Act, 2016: No Deposit or Advance Without Agreement for Sale
sections.section_description: The promoter is prohibited from accepting more than 10% of the cost of the apartment as an advance without executing a registered agreement for sale. This is relevant since the respondents failed to execute the agreement despite receiving payment.

sections.section_title: Section 71 of the RERA Act, 2016: Power of Adjudicating Officer
sections.section_description: This section empowers the Adjudicating Officer to adjudicate on matters concerning compensation and interest payable to allottees for violations by the promoter under RERA.

strong_points: The case demonstrates the mechanism of transferring complaints to the Adjudicating Officer for compensation decisions under RERA.
MahaRERA is proactive in addressing omissions and ensuring that the compensation process is handled correctly.
weak_points: The lack of a defense from the respondents leaves the complainants' claims largely unchallenged, but the case still needs adjudication for compensation details.

case_title: Complaint No. CC006000000192814 - Karan Chopra vs Skystar Buildcon Pvt Ltd
case_description: Karan Chopra filed a complaint against Skystar Buildcon Pvt Ltd seeking directions to obtain a full Occupancy Certificate, provide possession, and pay compensation for delayed possession of two flats (Nos. 603 and 604) in the project 'Sunteck City Avenue 1'. The complainant seeks relief under Sections 12, 14, 18, and 19 of the RERA for the delayed possession and misrepresentation about the possession date.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Refund and Compensation for Delays
sections.section_description: This section entitles allottees to seek a refund, compensation, and interest if the promoter fails to complete the project or deliver possession in accordance with the agreement. This applies to the delayed possession of flats Nos. 603 and 604.

sections.section_title: Section 12 of the RERA Act, 2016: Obligations Regarding False Representation
sections.section_description: If any false representation is made about the project, allottees are entitled to seek compensation for the loss or mental harassment caused. This aligns with the complainant's claim of misrepresentation about the possession date.

sections.section_title: Section 14 of the RERA Act, 2016: Adherence to Sanctioned Plans
sections.section_description: The promoter must ensure that the project adheres to the approved plans, specifications, and timelines. Any deviation entitles the allottee to seek compensation or rectification.

sections.section_title: Section 71 of the RERA Act, 2016: Power of Adjudicating Officer
sections.section_description: This section empowers the Adjudicating Officer to decide on compensation and interest payable to allottees for violations under RERA. It is relevant as the case has been referred to the Adjudicating Officer for a decision.

strong_points: MahaRERA effectively identified the complainant's entitlement to compensation under Section 18(3) of RERA.
The case demonstrates the use of the Conciliation Forum before escalating to the Adjudicating Officer.
weak_points: The case has been delayed due to the failure to reach a conciliation agreement and the absence of the respondent's initial reply.

case_title: Complaint No. CC006000000193280 - Renuka Sheth vs Era Realtors Pvt Ltd & Omkar Realtors & Developers Pvt Ltd
case_description: Renuka Sheth filed a complaint seeking a refund of the full amount paid for flat no. 1503 in the project 'Alta Monte and Signet' under Section 18 of RERA, citing the failure of the respondents to hand over possession of the flat within the agreed timeline. Despite a registered agreement, the respondents failed to deliver possession by March 31, 2020, and the project was delayed due to force majeure (COVID-19). The case was referred to the Adjudicating Officer for deciding the quantum of compensation under Section 18 of RERA.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Return of Amount and Compensation
sections.section_description: If the promoter fails to complete the project or hand over possession within the agreed timeline, the allottee is entitled to seek a refund of the amount paid, along with interest and compensation. This applies directly to the complainant's claim for refund and compensation.

sections.section_title: Section 6 of the RERA Act, 2016: Extension of Registration Due to Force Majeure
sections.section_description: This section allows for the extension of the project registration in case of force majeure events, such as the COVID-19 pandemic. The respondents cited this provision to justify the delay in possession.

sections.section_title: Section 13 of the RERA Act, 2016: No Deposit or Advance Without Agreement for Sale
sections.section_description: Promoters cannot accept more than 10% of the property price without executing a registered agreement for sale. Since the possession timeline was breached despite a registered agreement, this section reinforces the complainant's right to compensation.

sections.section_title: Section 71 of the RERA Act, 2016: Power of Adjudicating Officer
sections.section_description: This section empowers the Adjudicating Officer to adjudicate compensation claims. The case being referred for determining the compensation amount is consistent with this provision.

strong_points: The complainant's claim for a refund and compensation is backed by the failure of the respondents to deliver possession of the flat on time, as stipulated in the agreement.
The case was appropriately transferred to the Adjudicating Officer for a fair decision on compensation under RERA.
weak_points: The respondents cited the COVID-19 pandemic as a force majeure event, which might weaken the complainant’s position regarding the timeline for possession.
The revised completion date of June 30, 2024, introduces further delays, which may complicate the complainant's case for a full refund.

case_title: Complaint No. CC005000000010700 - Mr. Shrant Gour & Dr. Purnima Gour vs Lake District Realty Private Limited & Pune Kondhwa Realty Private Limited
case_description: Mr. Shrant Gour and Dr. Purnima Gour filed a complaint seeking relief under Section 18 of RERA, requesting the handover of possession and a refund of the full consideration paid for flat no. 6602 in the project 'Cove - Lake District - Phase II'. The complainants sought compensation for the delayed possession. However, MahaRERA observed that the respondent, Lake District Realty Private Limited, was undergoing Corporate Insolvency Resolution Process (CIRP), as per NCLT proceedings initiated against them. As a result, the case was adjourned, with the complainants directed to file their claims before the CIRP, if any.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Return of Amount and Compensation
sections.section_description: This section entitles allottees to a refund of the amount paid, along with interest and compensation, if the promoter fails to complete the project or hand over possession as per the agreed timeline. The complainants sought relief under this section.

sections.section_title: Section 13 of the RERA Act, 2016: No Deposit or Advance Without Agreement for Sale
sections.section_description: Promoters cannot accept more than 10% of the property cost as an advance without executing a registered agreement for sale. This reinforces the complainants' rights under the agreement.

sections.section_title: Section 14 of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016: Moratorium During CIRP
sections.section_description: This section imposes a moratorium during the Corporate Insolvency Resolution Process (CIRP), prohibiting the continuation of legal proceedings against the corporate debtor. This provision was applied by MahaRERA to adjourn the case.

sections.section_title: Section 7 of the MOFA Act, 1963: Adherence to Approved Plans
sections.section_description: The promoter is obligated to adhere to the approved plans and timelines specified in the agreement. Any deviation or delay may entitle the allottee to seek remedies under the law.

strong_points: The complainants were proactive in seeking relief under Section 18 of RERA, highlighting the delay in possession and the need for compensation.
MahaRERA recognized the CIRP proceedings and appropriately adjourned the case in accordance with the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code.
weak_points: The respondent's insolvency status prohibited the immediate resolution of the complaint, delaying the resolution process for the complainants.
The complainants may face additional delays as the CIRP process takes precedence over RERA proceedings.

case_title: Complaint No. CC005000000011054 - Vikas Pandit Kirange vs Naiknavare Housing Developments Pvt. Ltd.
case_description: Vikas Pandit Kirange filed a complaint seeking a refund of the amount paid for the 'Dwarka Project 2', along with rent compensation and interest due to delayed possession. The complainant had initially withdrawn the complaint in 2018 after a mutual settlement, but later filed for non-compliance of the agreed terms. MahaRERA transferred the case to the Secretary, MahaRERA for further action after unsuccessful conciliation attempts.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Return of Amount and Compensation
sections.section_description: This section entitles allottees to seek a refund, along with interest and compensation, in case of delayed possession or non-compliance with the terms of the agreement. It supports the complainant’s claims for rent compensation and interest.

sections.section_title: Section 11(4)(e) of the RERA Act, 2016: Formation of Allottee Association
sections.section_description: Promoters are required to facilitate the formation of an allottee association. Non-compliance with agreements or settlements made with the association can lead to further legal obligations for the promoter.

sections.section_title: Section 13 of the RERA Act, 2016: No Deposit or Advance Without Agreement for Sale
sections.section_description: Promoters cannot collect more than 10% of the property cost without a registered agreement for sale. The complainant’s claim for compliance with settlement terms aligns with obligations under this section.

sections.section_title: Section 7 of the MOFA Act, 1963: Adherence to Approved Plans
sections.section_description: The promoter is obligated to adhere to the approved plans and timelines as per agreements. Any deviation entitles the allottee to seek remedies, including compensation for delays or non-compliance.

strong_points: The complainant was proactive in filing for non-compliance after the settlement, ensuring that the issue of delayed possession was addressed.
MahaRERA appropriately transferred the case to the Secretary for further action, considering the non-compliance and failed conciliation attempts.
weak_points: The initial settlement in 2018 and the complainant’s subsequent withdrawal of the case weakened their position.
The respondent's request for more time and objections to the clarity of the complaint caused delays in the resolution of the matter.

case_title: Complaint No. CC006000000000534 - Sohail Moosa vs Enkay Castle
case_description: Sohail Moosa filed a complaint seeking interest and compensation for delayed possession and non-provision of amenities in the project 'Enkay Garden - Zenia' under Section 18 of RERA. The complainant sought compensation for the delayed possession, non-availability of the occupancy certificate, and the failure to provide the agreed amenities as per the agreement for sale, including a school, hospital, and lift. The MahaRERA noted that the respondent failed to appear in hearings and decided the case ex-parte.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Return of Amount and Compensation
sections.section_description: This section entitles allottees to seek a refund, compensation, and interest if the promoter fails to deliver possession or provide agreed amenities within the stipulated timeline. The complainant’s claim for delayed possession, non-provision of amenities, and lack of an occupancy certificate falls under this section.

sections.section_title: Section 14 of the RERA Act, 2016: Adherence to Sanctioned Plans
sections.section_description: Promoters must adhere to sanctioned plans and specifications, including promised amenities like schools, hospitals, and lifts. Failure to provide these facilities constitutes a breach of the agreement.

sections.section_title: Section 31 of the RERA Act, 2016: Filing of Complaints with MahaRERA
sections.section_description: This section empowers allottees to file complaints against promoters for non-compliance with RERA provisions. It underpins the complainant's right to file and pursue their case.

sections.section_title: Section 71 of the RERA Act, 2016: Power of Adjudicating Officer
sections.section_description: This section authorizes the Adjudicating Officer to adjudicate matters related to compensation and interest. The case being transferred to the Adjudicating Officer aligns with this section.

strong_points: The complainant emphasized the failure of the respondent to provide essential amenities and the lack of an occupancy certificate, which are significant issues under RERA.
MahaRERA's decision to proceed ex-parte highlighted the respondent's lack of participation in the proceedings.
weak_points: The complainant had already taken possession of the flat in 2015, which could have weakened the case for compensation based on delayed possession.
The respondent did not provide a defense or appear at the hearings, which could imply non-compliance with MahaRERA’s procedural requirements.

case_title: Complaint No. CC005000000053914 - Suchet P. Padhye vs Marvel Omega Builders Pvt. Ltd. & Marvel Realtors & Developers Pvt. Ltd.
case_description: Suchet P. Padhye and Zareen S. Padhye filed a complaint under Section 18 of RERA seeking interest and compensation due to a delay in possession of flat No. B-1102 in the project 'Marvel Cerise Building B,C & D', Pune. The complainants made full payment and were to receive possession by December 31, 2013, but possession was only delivered on March 1, 2019, after a delay of 1885 days. The respondents cited a supplementary agreement extending the possession date to September 2017, arguing for the dismissal of the complaint. MahaRERA transferred the case to the Adjudicating Officer for determination of the compensation.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Return of Amount and Compensation
sections.section_description: If the promoter fails to deliver possession as per the agreement, the allottee is entitled to seek a refund or claim compensation with interest for the delay. This section directly addresses the complainants' claim of delayed possession by 1885 days.

sections.section_title: Section 13 of the RERA Act, 2016: No Deposit or Advance Without Agreement for Sale
sections.section_description: The promoter is prohibited from collecting more than 10% of the total cost without executing a registered agreement for sale. The supplementary agreement cited by the respondents to extend the possession timeline is relevant under this section.

sections.section_title: Section 14 of the RERA Act, 2016: Adherence to Sanctioned Plans
sections.section_description: Promoters must adhere to approved project plans and timelines. Deviations, such as delayed possession, entitle allottees to remedies, including compensation or rectification.

sections.section_title: Section 71 of the RERA Act, 2016: Power of Adjudicating Officer
sections.section_description: This section empowers the Adjudicating Officer to decide on compensation and interest. The case being transferred to the Adjudicating Officer aligns with this provision.

strong_points: The complainants emphasized the significant delay of 1885 days in receiving possession, which is a major lapse on the part of the respondents.
MahaRERA acknowledged the applicability of Section 18 of RERA, entitling the complainants to seek compensation.
weak_points: The respondents presented a supplementary agreement that extended the possession date, which could potentially weaken the complainants' case for compensation.
The complainants had already taken possession of the flat, which may affect the outcome regarding the quantum of compensation.

case_title: Complaint No. CC005000000022943 - Pravin S. Nar-lkarri vs Clover Developers Pvt. Ltd. & Anr.
case_description: Pravin S. Nar-lkarri filed a complaint challenging the construction of buildings Nos. 8 & 9 on land meant for common amenities in the 'Clover Highlands' project. The complainant, an allottee in Building No. 21, contended that his undivided share in the common land was violated, and that the consumption of full FSI for construction was illegal. He sought redress under Section 31 of RERA, citing violations of Maharashtra Real Estate (Regulation and Development) Rules, 2017. However, the case was complicated by a pending civil suit on the same issue and the respondent’s contention that the matter was sub judice.

sections.section_title: Section 31 of the RERA Act, 2016: Filing of Complaints with MahaRERA
sections.section_description: This section empowers any aggrieved person to file a complaint regarding violations of RERA provisions or rules. The complainant invoked this section to challenge the construction on land designated for common amenities.

sections.section_title: Section 14 of the RERA Act, 2016: Adherence to Sanctioned Plans
sections.section_description: Promoters must adhere to the sanctioned plans and project specifications. Any deviation, such as constructing buildings on land meant for common amenities, constitutes a violation of this section.

sections.section_title: Section 7 of the MOFA Act, 1963: Adherence to Approved Plans
sections.section_description: This section mandates that promoters adhere to approved layouts and plans as per agreements. The complainant’s objection to using FSI for unauthorized construction aligns with this provision.

sections.section_title: Section 3 of the RERA Act, 2016: Prior Registration of Real Estate Projects
sections.section_description: All ongoing and new real estate projects must be registered with MahaRERA. If the disputed buildings were not part of the registered project plan, this section could apply to assess compliance.

strong_points: The complainant had a legitimate concern regarding his undivided interest in the common land, raising important issues under Section 31 of RERA.
The civil court’s involvement and the dismissal of related writ petitions did not preclude RERA’s examination of potential violations of rules related to the registered project.
weak_points: The complainant's case was complicated by the pending civil suit, which dealt with the same issues, reducing the clarity and effectiveness of the RERA complaint.
MahaRERA found that the dispute over the common land and FSI usage was primarily within the jurisdiction of civil courts, weakening the case's standing under RERA.

case_title: Complaint No. CC006000000195650 - Manju Somani & Gaurav Somani vs Raja Builders
case_description: Manju Somani and Gaurav Somani filed a complaint seeking a refund of the balance amount of Rs. 25,00,000, following the cancellation of a sale transaction for a flat in the 'Raja Builders' project. The complainants claim to have received a partial refund, but they are entitled to the remaining amount as per mutual understanding. The respondent argues that the entire consideration has been refunded and that the complaint is improperly filed with the MahaRERA Authority instead of the Adjudicating Officer.

sections.section_title: Section 12 of the RERA Act, 2016: Obligations Regarding False Representation
sections.section_description: If a promoter provides false or misleading information or violates the terms of an agreement, the allottee is entitled to compensation or a refund with interest. This section applies to the complainants' claim that the respondent violated the terms of mutual understanding.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Return of Amount and Compensation
sections.section_description: This section entitles allottees to a refund of the amount paid, along with interest and compensation, if the promoter fails to comply with the terms of an agreement or mutual understanding.

sections.section_title: Section 71 of the RERA Act, 2016: Power of Adjudicating Officer
sections.section_description: This section empowers the Adjudicating Officer to decide on matters related to compensation and refunds. The respondent's contention that the case should be filed with the Adjudicating Officer rather than MahaRERA aligns with this provision.

sections.section_title: Section 4 of the MOFA Act, 1963: Obligation to Execute Agreement for Sale
sections.section_description: Promoters are obligated to execute a clear and legally binding agreement for sale. Any deviations or disputes arising from this agreement may result in claims for compensation or refunds.

strong_points: The complainants provided evidence of a partial refund and a claim for the remaining balance of Rs. 25,00,000.
MahaRERA recognized the need for a full evaluation of the respondent's defense at the final hearing.
weak_points: The respondent's defense, supported by documentary evidence, indicated that the full amount had already been refunded.
The complaint was filed with the MahaRERA Authority rather than the Adjudicating Officer, as required for monetary claims.

case_title: Complaint No. CC006000000012041 - Sanjeev Sharma vs Ravi Developments
case_description: Sanjeev Sharma filed a complaint against Ravi Developments for failure to deliver possession of his apartment in the 'Gaurav Aster' project within the stipulated time frame. Although the construction up to the 10th floor was completed, the complainant has not received possession due to incomplete amenities and the lack of an occupancy certificate. The complainant seeks to have possession handed over and to claim interest for the delay.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Return of Amount and Compensation
sections.section_description: If the promoter fails to deliver possession in accordance with the terms of the agreement, the allottee is entitled to claim interest or a refund with compensation. This section directly addresses the complainant’s claim for delayed possession and interest.

sections.section_title: Section 14 of the RERA Act, 2016: Adherence to Sanctioned Plans
sections.section_description: Promoters are obligated to complete the project as per sanctioned plans and timelines, including obtaining necessary approvals like the occupancy certificate. Failure to do so constitutes a breach of this section.

sections.section_title: Section 19 of the RERA Act, 2016: Rights and Duties of Allottees
sections.section_description: Allottees have the right to demand possession as per the agreement, along with essential amenities and required approvals. They are also entitled to claim interest or compensation for delays caused by the promoter.

sections.section_title: Section 7 of the MOFA Act, 1963: Adherence to Approved Plans
sections.section_description: Under MOFA, promoters must adhere to the approved plans and timelines agreed upon with the allottees. The lack of an occupancy certificate and incomplete amenities breaches this obligation.

strong_points: The Respondent acknowledged the completion of construction but failed to deliver the occupancy certificate, affecting possession.
The complainant has the legal right under Section 18 to demand interest for the delay in possession.
weak_points: The Respondent claimed that the possession was offered multiple times but was not accepted by the complainant.
The project was still under development, with amenities and certain floors unfinished, which contributed to the delay.

case_title: Complaint No. CC006000000193924 - Jaikumar Gupta HUF vs Realgem Buildtech Pvt. Ltd.
case_description: Jaikumar Gupta HUF filed a complaint seeking a refund and compensation for the delay in possession of a flat in the project 'Rustomjee Crown - Phase I.' The complainant requested a refund under Section 18 of RERA, citing the delay in possession, along with interest and compensation. The MahaRERA noted that the complainant had filed two separate complaints for the same cause of action, leading to confusion about the relief sought. Ultimately, one complaint was withdrawn, and the other was retained for final hearing.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Return of Amount and Compensation
sections.section_description: If the promoter fails to complete the project or hand over possession as per the agreement, the allottee is entitled to a refund along with interest and compensation. This section forms the basis of the complainant’s demand for a refund and interest.

sections.section_title: Section 13 of the RERA Act, 2016: No Deposit or Advance Without Agreement for Sale
sections.section_description: Promoters cannot accept more than 10% of the property cost as an advance without executing a registered agreement for sale. The arbitration clause within the agreement becomes relevant under this provision.

sections.section_title: Section 71 of the RERA Act, 2016: Power of Adjudicating Officer
sections.section_description: This section empowers the Adjudicating Officer to decide matters related to compensation, including refunds and interest. It is relevant to the complainant’s demand for financial remedies.

sections.section_title: Section 8 of the Arbitration and Conciliation Act, 1996
sections.section_description: This section requires disputes to be referred to arbitration if an arbitration clause exists in the agreement. The respondent’s defense relies on this provision, questioning the maintainability of the complaint.

strong_points: The complainant raised valid concerns regarding the delay in possession and sought appropriate relief under Section 18 of RERA.
MahaRERA provided clarity by allowing the complainant to retain one complaint for final hearing after addressing the confusion caused by two complaints.
weak_points: The respondent's argument about the arbitration clause in the agreement raised doubts about the appropriateness of the RERA forum for resolving the dispute.
The complainant’s filing of two complaints for the same issue complicated the proceedings and led to procedural delays.

case_title: Complaint No. CC006000000196910 - Krishnan Pich Mani & Sindhu Krishnan vs Nirmal Lifestyle (Kalyan) Private Limited
case_description: Krishnan Pich Mani and Sindhu Krishnan filed a complaint seeking directions from MahaRERA to refund the amounts paid for flat no. 704 in the 'Lifestyle City Kalyan - Platano E' project, citing a delay in possession. The respondent, Nirmal Lifestyle (Kalyan) Pvt. Ltd., was undergoing a Corporate Insolvency Resolution Process (CIRP), and the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT) had imposed a moratorium on legal proceedings against the respondent. MahaRERA deferred its decision, pending the outcome of the insolvency proceedings, and adjourned the complaint sine die with liberty for the complainants to approach MahaRERA post-disposal of the insolvency case.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Return of Amount and Compensation
sections.section_description: If the promoter fails to deliver possession or fulfill the terms of the agreement, the allottee is entitled to seek a refund with interest and compensation. The complainants relied on this section for their refund and compensation claim.

sections.section_title: Section 14 of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016: Moratorium During CIRP
sections.section_description: This section imposes a moratorium during the Corporate Insolvency Resolution Process (CIRP), preventing legal proceedings against the corporate debtor. MahaRERA deferred its decision under the moratorium imposed by the NCLT.

sections.section_title: Section 71 of the RERA Act, 2016: Power of Adjudicating Officer
sections.section_description: This section empowers the Adjudicating Officer to decide on compensation and refunds. However, the complaint was deferred as the NCLT moratorium restricted proceedings.

sections.section_title: Section 7 of the MOFA Act, 1963: Adherence to Approved Plans
sections.section_description: The promoter is obligated to adhere to approved plans and timelines under MOFA. The complainants' claim for refunds is indirectly tied to the promoter's failure to meet agreed deadlines, but this remains subordinate to the insolvency process.

strong_points: The complainants highlighted the legal precedent from the Supreme Court, arguing that the moratorium does not prevent proceedings against the promoters directly.
MahaRERA provided a fair hearing and acknowledged the legal constraints imposed by the NCLT proceedings.
weak_points: The complainants failed to include the directors of the respondent company in the complaint, limiting the scope of legal action available under RERA.
Despite the complainants' arguments, MahaRERA could not proceed with the case due to the ongoing insolvency proceedings and the moratorium.

case_title: Complaint No. CC006000000090122 - Jesa G. Patel (HUF) vs Swastik Realty Pvt. Ltd., RajendraLaxmanWani, KalpanaRajendraWani
case_description: Jesa G. Patel (HUF) filed a complaint seeking directions from MahaRERA to the respondents, Swastik Realty Pvt. Ltd., Rajendra Laxman Wani, and Kalpana Rajendra Wani, to execute an agreement for sale and pay interest for delayed possession under RERA. The complainant also sought compensation for mental agony due to delayed possession and false information provided by the respondents, including the sale of a flat to a third party without the complainant’s consent. The complaint was initially heard by MahaRERA, which transferred the case to the Ld. Adjudicating Officer for further adjudication and compensation under RERA.

sections.section_title: Section 13 of the RERA Act, 2016: No Deposit or Advance Without Agreement for Sale
sections.section_description: This section prohibits promoters from accepting more than 10% of the total cost of the apartment without executing a registered agreement for sale. The complainant's demand for executing an agreement for sale aligns with this section.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Return of Amount and Compensation
sections.section_description: This section allows the allottee to seek compensation, interest, or a refund if the promoter fails to deliver possession as per the agreement. It is directly applicable to the complainant's claim for delayed possession and compensation.

sections.section_title: Section 12 of the RERA Act, 2016: Obligations Regarding False Representation
sections.section_description: If the promoter provides false or misleading information, the allottee is entitled to compensation for the loss incurred. This applies to the complainant's claim of false information and the unauthorized sale of a flat to a third party.

sections.section_title: Section 14 of the RERA Act, 2016: Adherence to Sanctioned Plans
sections.section_description: This section mandates that promoters adhere to sanctioned plans and prohibits changes without the consent of two-thirds of the allottees. The complainant's grievance regarding amendments to plans without consent falls under this section.

strong_points: The complainant clearly stated the violations under Sections 12 and 14, highlighting the false information provided and unauthorized sale of the flat to a third party.
MahaRERA promptly transferred the case to the appropriate authority (the Ld. Adjudicating Officer) for further action, ensuring that the complainant’s issues would be addressed.
weak_points: The text does not provide the respondent's defense, leaving the case somewhat one-sided in the information provided.
The complaint was transferred without a final decision, which may cause a delay in resolution for the complainant.

case_title: Complaint No. CC006000000396998 - MDP Partners (Mr. Paranjape) vs Avarsekar Realty Pvt Ltd
case_description: MDP Partners (Mr. Paranjape) filed a complaint before MahaRERA seeking directions to the respondent, Avarsekar Realty Pvt Ltd, to upload project-related documents as required under Sections 4 and 11 of the Real Estate (Regulation & Development) Act, 2016 (RERA) for the registered project 'Shristi Sea View' in Mumbai. During the proceedings, MahaRERA discovered that the respondent was undergoing insolvency proceedings under the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code (IBC), 2016. As per the order from the National Company Law Tribunal (NCLT), a moratorium was imposed, preventing any legal proceedings against the respondent. Consequently, MahaRERA adjourned the case sine die, granting the complainant the liberty to approach MahaRERA after the insolvency case is resolved.

sections.section_title: Section 4 of the RERA Act, 2016: Application for Registration of Real Estate Projects
sections.section_description: Promoters are required to submit project-related documents, including sanctioned plans, layout approvals, and timelines for project completion, as part of the registration process. The complainant sought compliance with this section for the 'Shristi Sea View' project.

sections.section_title: Section 11 of the RERA Act, 2016: Obligations of the Promoter
sections.section_description: This section obligates promoters to provide accurate project details, update information regularly, and ensure transparency in project status. The complainant's request for document uploads aligns with these obligations.

sections.section_title: Section 14 of the Insolvency and Bankruptcy Code, 2016: Moratorium During CIRP
sections.section_description: This section imposes a moratorium during the Corporate Insolvency Resolution Process (CIRP), preventing legal proceedings against the corporate debtor. MahaRERA adjourned the case sine die due to the moratorium imposed by the NCLT.

sections.section_title: Section 71 of the RERA Act, 2016: Power of Adjudicating Officer
sections.section_description: This section empowers the Adjudicating Officer to address violations and determine compliance with RERA provisions. However, due to the moratorium, the proceedings were paused pending the resolution of insolvency proceedings.

strong_points: MahaRERA promptly identified the impact of the ongoing insolvency proceedings and took the appropriate legal action by deferring the case.
The complainant was informed of the ongoing insolvency process, and the option to revisit the case after resolution was clearly communicated.
weak_points: The respondent's failure to appear for the hearing and the absence of any defense or explanation weakens the transparency of the case.
The case cannot proceed until the insolvency proceedings are resolved, delaying a resolution for the complainant.

case_title: Complaint No. CC006000000110754 - Rupinder Elavia vs Aryamaan Developers Private Limited
case_description: Rupinder Elavia filed a complaint before MahaRERA seeking a refund of the amount paid along with interest and compensation under Section 18 of the Real Estate (Regulation & Development) Act, 2016 (RERA) for the booking of a flat in Aryamaan Developers' project 'Centrona Nova B' in Ghatkopar East, Mumbai. The complainant alleged delays in possession and misleading information regarding the project completion date. Despite the interim order passed by MahaRERA on 08-10-2020 transferring the case to the Adjudicating Officer, the respondent claimed no obligation was violated. The matter was further complicated by an ongoing appeal, which resulted in the adjournment of the case sine die until the appeal was decided.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Return of Amount and Compensation
sections.section_description: This section allows allottees to claim a refund, interest, or compensation if the promoter fails to deliver possession as per the agreement. The complainant's request for a refund and compensation is directly based on this provision.

sections.section_title: Section 12 of the RERA Act, 2016: Obligations Regarding False Representation
sections.section_description: If a promoter provides misleading or false information about the project, the allottee is entitled to compensation for the resulting loss. The complainant's allegation of misleading information regarding the possession date aligns with this section.

sections.section_title: Section 71 of the RERA Act, 2016: Power of Adjudicating Officer
sections.section_description: This section empowers the Adjudicating Officer to adjudicate claims for refunds and compensation. The transfer of the case to the Adjudicating Officer is based on this provision.

sections.section_title: Section 44 of the RERA Act, 2016: Appeal to the Appellate Tribunal
sections.section_description: This section governs appeals against orders passed by MahaRERA or the Adjudicating Officer. The ongoing appeal challenging the interim order made this section relevant and led to the case's adjournment.

strong_points: MahaRERA provided clear guidance on the procedural status of the case and the impact of the pending appeal on further proceedings.
The complainant was granted a reasonable opportunity to pursue the appeal, keeping the case under review.
weak_points: The case is delayed due to the ongoing appeal, leaving the complainant without a final resolution for a prolonged period.
The respondent's defense of no violation is unchallenged until the appeal is resolved, which may prolong the legal process.

case_title: Complaint No. CC006000000056050 - Dhanraj Rajpal vs Benchmark Projects Pvt Ltd & Complaint No. CC006000000056049 - Neeta Rajpal vs Benchmark Projects Pvt Ltd
case_description: Dhanraj Rajpal and Neeta Rajpal filed separate complaints before MahaRERA, alleging that the respondent, Benchmark Projects Pvt Ltd, failed to hand over possession of commercial units in the project 'Benchmark Plaza' situated in Andheri, Mumbai, within the stipulated timeline. The complainants also alleged deficiencies in the carpet area of the commercial units and violations of BMC norms. They requested that the respondent rectify the violations, obtain the occupancy certificate (OC), and hand over possession. Additionally, they sought compensation for the delay in possession. The respondent argued that the delay was due to factors beyond their control and claimed that the complainants were already in possession and conducting business from the units. The case is ongoing, with the prayer for interest on delayed possession to be adjudicated once the project obtains the OC.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Return of Amount and Compensation
sections.section_description: This section entitles allottees to claim compensation, interest, or a refund if the promoter fails to deliver possession within the stipulated time. The complainants' request for compensation for delayed possession aligns with this provision.

sections.section_title: Section 14 of the RERA Act, 2016: Adherence to Sanctioned Plans
sections.section_description: Promoters are required to adhere to approved plans and specifications. The complainants' allegations of BMC norm violations and carpet area deficiencies relate to this section.

sections.section_title: Section 11 of the RERA Act, 2016: Obligations of the Promoter
sections.section_description: This section mandates promoters to complete the project as per the approved timeline and provide regular updates. The requirement to obtain the occupancy certificate (OC) and complete remaining work aligns with the promoter's obligations under this section.

sections.section_title: Section 19 of the RERA Act, 2016: Rights and Duties of Allottees
sections.section_description: Allottees have the right to demand possession along with essential documentation like the occupancy certificate. The complainants’ request to ensure compliance with BMC norms and obtain the OC aligns with this section.

strong_points: MahaRERA clarified that the issue of interest for delayed possession would be addressed at a later stage, ensuring the parties understood the procedural steps ahead.
The authority took a balanced approach, allowing the respondent time to complete the project work and obtain the OC while addressing the complainants' concerns.
weak_points: The case has been delayed, and the complainants' request for interest on delayed possession is still pending, which could result in frustration for the parties involved.
While the respondent intends to obtain the part occupancy certificate, the timeline for completion remains uncertain, prolonging the resolution of the case.

case_title: Complaint No. CC005000000023401 - Pallavi Ambaldhage & Mangala Ambaldhage vs Amit Ashok Thepade, Deepak Amrutlal Gugale, Roshan Ramesh Dusane
case_description: Pallavi Ambaldhage and Mangala Ambaldhage filed a complaint seeking possession of flat no. 403 in the 'Galaxy One' project under Section 18 of RERA, citing non-delivery of possession by the promised date and deficiencies in construction. The respondents claimed that they had received the part occupancy certificate and offered possession, but the complainants refused to take possession without making the balance payment. The case was transferred to the Adjudicating Officer for compensation determination.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Return of Amount and Compensation
sections.section_description: This section entitles allottees to claim possession, interest, or compensation if the promoter fails to deliver possession by the agreed date. The complainants' claim for possession, interest, and compensation directly falls under this section.

sections.section_title: Section 14 of the RERA Act, 2016: Adherence to Sanctioned Plans
sections.section_description: This section mandates that promoters must adhere to sanctioned plans and specifications. The complainants' concerns about construction defects and incomplete promised amenities are addressed under this section.

sections.section_title: Section 11 of the RERA Act, 2016: Obligations of the Promoter
sections.section_description: Promoters are obligated to complete the project as per the approved timeline and provide all required approvals, including occupancy certificates. The respondents' delay and partial compliance align with issues addressed under this section.

sections.section_title: Section 71 of the RERA Act, 2016: Power of Adjudicating Officer
sections.section_description: This section empowers the Adjudicating Officer to adjudicate claims for compensation. The transfer of the complaint to the Adjudicating Officer aligns with this provision.

strong_points: The complainants highlighted the delayed possession and construction defects, which violated the agreement and RERA provisions.
The respondents' failure to fully comply with the promised amenities and construction quality warranted a compensation review.
weak_points: The respondents had received the part occupancy certificate, which could mitigate some of the complainants' claims for non-possession.
The complainants refused to take possession despite the respondents offering it, citing unresolved payment issues.

case_title: Non-Execution Application in Complaint No. CC005000000011612 - Mr. Tukaram Dhage vs M/s. Vastushilp Builders and Developers
case_description: Mr. Tukaram Dhage filed a non-execution application seeking a refund of the entire amount paid, along with interest and compensation under Section 18 of RERA. This was due to the respondent's failure to comply with the order dated 5th October 2018, which directed them to complete the pending work within three months. MahaRERA observed that the respondent neglected to fulfill the directions and transferred the case to the Adjudicating Officer for further decision on compensation.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Return of Amount and Compensation
sections.section_description: This section allows allottees to seek a refund, interest, and compensation if the promoter fails to deliver possession as per the agreement or comply with orders issued by MahaRERA. The complainant’s claim is directly based on this provision.

sections.section_title: Section 40 of the RERA Act, 2016: Recovery of Interest or Penalty or Compensation
sections.section_description: This section provides mechanisms to recover compensation, interest, or penalties imposed under RERA. It supports the complainant’s non-execution application, as the respondent failed to comply with an earlier MahaRERA order.

sections.section_title: Section 11 of the RERA Act, 2016: Obligations of the Promoter
sections.section_description: Promoters must adhere to timelines and ensure compliance with orders issued by MahaRERA. The respondent’s failure to complete the work within the directed timeline breaches this obligation.

sections.section_title: Section 71 of the RERA Act, 2016: Power of Adjudicating Officer
sections.section_description: This section empowers the Adjudicating Officer to determine the quantum of compensation in cases involving refunds and financial claims. The case transfer aligns with this provision.

strong_points: The complainant highlighted the respondent’s complete failure to comply with a binding MahaRERA order, justifying their claim for a refund and compensation.
MahaRERA acknowledged the non-compliance and transferred the case for appropriate adjudication under Section 18 of RERA.
weak_points: The respondent did not appear to present any defense, leaving the complaint unchallenged during the hearing.
There is no evidence in the provided text indicating that the respondent attempted partial compliance or sought an extension.

case_title: Complaint Nos. CC006000000192257 & CC006000000251688 - Megha Prashant Jadhav and Prasad Prasannan Poozhipurathu vs M/s. Enkay Castle
case_description: Megha Prashant Jadhav and Prasad Prasannan Poozhipurathu filed two separate complaints seeking a refund of the full amount paid for their respective flats in the project 'Enkay Garden – Bluebell,' along with interest under Section 18 of RERA. The complainants argued that the project is at a standstill, and the registration with MahaRERA has not been extended. Although the respondent failed to appear for the hearing, MahaRERA granted them one final opportunity to present their case, adhering to the principles of natural justice.

sections.section_title: Section 18 of the RERA Act, 2016: Return of Amount and Compensation
